Rules:
  • Standard site rules are in place; you should REALLY know these by now.
  • Deadlines: Days are three weeks (or until lynch); nights are three days (except weekend-nights which're four). Failure to submit an action or obtain majority on a lynch, and it is forfeit.
  • Voting must be bolded or in vote tags to be counted. If I recognize who it's for, it counts.
  • I'll send out Prods after three days, but will poke players on request before then. They must post within two days and cannot let themselves receive five prods, or they'll be replaced.
  • Have fun, but don't be a jerkass. Seriously, I'll force-replace you if you prove toxic to the game's atmosphere.
  • MISCELLANEOUS:
    1. I do allow contentless "bah" posts with no restriction other than lacking game content.
    2. <<< Pure, bolded black within these marks is my modding color. There's no way to accidentally use these; DON'T USE THEM. >>>
    3. Golden rule? ASK! I'll do what I can to answer. Got a complaint? Raise it, and I'll do what I can.
    4. Loophole abuse will be treated just as seriously as (if not moreso than) the actual crime. Seriously. Just don't. The game's meant to be FUN, and if you're seeking loopholes, you're not in the right game. (For instance, I take very poorly to prod-dodges. Just announce V/LA.)
  • GAME SPECIFIC:
    1. This game is explicitly 10:3 town:mafia.
    2. Any and all game topics will remain open the entire game.
    3. The mafia may both kill and action.
    4. This game was reviewed for normalcy/balance by mhsmith0, Firebringer, and Cheery Dog.
    5. The following is the sample town PM:
      Vanilla Townie wrote:Welcome to Mini Normal 1873, Playername.
      You are a Vanilla Townie.
      Your only weapons are your voice and your vote.

      You win when all threats to the town are eliminated, and at least one member of your faction is alive.

      The game thread is here.
      Please confirm your role via PM.

      Good luck and have fun!

The condition for my posting reasoning for my vote on All Alone has now been fulfilled. That condition was All Alone posting so as to see possible reaction / lack thereof in response to my vote.

Prior to my joining this site and signing up for this game I spent some time reading through a couple of the longer games on this site to get a feel for how the game was approached here (sidenote: super helpful, scumhunting tactics I picked up made me so much better in the game I'm currently in on my main site). One of the games in particular featured both All Alone and Alisae, providing a reference point for meta reads. At the time of my vote, Alisae had several votes on him as a result of his posting style and I decided that adding additional pressure to him was less beneficial than putting pressure on All Alone in an attempt to create reactions to base reads on him from.

Based on that previous game that I had read (which I believe is still ongoing last time I looked ~a week ago), I am reasonably confident that Alisae is town. His actions this game are entirely consistent with his behaviour in the previous game and his scumhunting, while arguable how effectual it is, follow similar patterns. That being said, I'm not willing to consider them a lock town at this point in time as their posting style inherently creates a looooot of noise that can hide more legitimate tells on them.

All Alone having posted is now grounds for me to place a FoS on them. Their previous meta as I interpreted it had them being, while not necessarily a lot more active, considerably more proactive in their scumhunting tactics. Their post 285 shows them unvoting as their only post of content since RVS based on "not wanting their vote anywhere" right now. While I'm willing to give this a pass for players who are more actively using their vote and have shown some kind of previous commitment to reads, his lack of activity on that front means that his unvote here looks considerably more like a scum who doesn't want their vote to be tied to someone they can be held accountable to for their opinions should they unvote and wagon in the future.

My scumhunting tactics are really more reactive than proactive, to be honest.

And also, I do expect to be held accountable for my opinions, even when my opinion is that I have no scumreads. That's why I came in here and admitted as much.

In post 1310, ThinkBig wrote:@MOD: Hypothetically in a Jailkeeper scenario, would a jailkeeper render its target untargetable by all other actions during that Night (i.e. cop, tracker, etc)?
No. That is not a jailkeeper.

The role which functions the way you describe is called an 'Alien', a hybrid of a Roleblocker and a Rolestopper: stops the target player from acting, and stops ALL actions targeting that player from working.

A Jailkeeper is a hybrid of a Roleblocker and a Doctor: stops the target player from acting, and stops NIGHTKILLS targeting that player from going through.

Or if you prefer, as per the wiki:
Variations
Some Jailkeepers not only protect their target from all kills, but also render its target untargetable by all other actions during that Night. This variant is also known as Alien.
Normal Guidelines wrote:Normal Guidelines
A Jailkeeper that simultaneously blocks and protects their target is considered Normal on mafiascum.net, provided that any mutual blocking scenarios are planned for during review. Any role that receives results (such as Tracker or Watcher) but is blocked should receive a "no result" message, rather than told their target didn't go anywhere or nobody visited their target. A Jailkeeper cannot stop a Strongman from committing a kill.
It should be noted that the clause "Any role that receives results but is blocked" is referring to the player TARGETED by the jailkeeper, NOT a player targeting the TARGET of the jailkeeper. (I'll raise the issue to Nexus about the unclear wording of that section.)

In post 1319, mastina wrote:
In post 1310, ThinkBig wrote:@MOD: Hypothetically in a Jailkeeper scenario, would a jailkeeper render its target untargetable by all other actions during that Night (i.e. cop, tracker, etc)?
No. That is not a jailkeeper.

The role which functions the way you describe is called an 'Alien', a hybrid of a Roleblocker and a Rolestopper: stops the target player from acting, and stops ALL actions targeting that player from working.

A Jailkeeper is a hybrid of a Roleblocker and a Doctor: stops the target player from acting, and stops NIGHTKILLS targeting that player from going through.

Or if you prefer, as per the wiki:
Variations
Some Jailkeepers not only protect their target from all kills, but also render its target untargetable by all other actions during that Night. This variant is also known as Alien.
Normal Guidelines wrote:Normal Guidelines
A Jailkeeper that simultaneously blocks and protects their target is considered Normal on mafiascum.net, provided that any mutual blocking scenarios are planned for during review. Any role that receives results (such as Tracker or Watcher) but is blocked should receive a "no result" message, rather than told their target didn't go anywhere or nobody visited their target. A Jailkeeper cannot stop a Strongman from committing a kill.
It should be noted that the clause "Any role that receives results but is blocked" is referring to the player TARGETED by the jailkeeper, NOT a player targeting the TARGET of the jailkeeper. (I'll raise the issue to Nexus about the unclear wording of that section.)

Since the issue has been raised by multiple people across multiple venues:
I cannot replace a player on hearsay. "I think player X is no longer playing the game" is not grounds for me to replace player X.
For me to replace a player, there needs to be a justified ground for me to replace that player: a reason to believe that player is unfit to play in the game or already isn't playing the game.

If player X explicitly requests replacement, that is grounds for me to replace them, as I have them explicitly saying that they are not playing the game anymore.
If player X fails to respond to a prod, that is grounds for me to replace them, as their failure to respond is an indication they are no longer playing the game anymore.
If player X requires forced replacement for any reason, that is obviously grounds for me to replace them, as the cause of the force-replace makes them unfit to play the game anymore.

These are established, universal guidelines on replacements.

If I can be given grounds to replace a slot, then I will replace the slot. The above three are universal moderator methods. They are not the only possible methods.

In this case, for the purpose of this game: if it can be shown that a player is no longer playing the game, then I will replace that player. Replacement requests or failure to respond to prods are the given universal methods of detecting this as a moderator. They are not the only possible methods, simply the methods I will default to as a moderator. Give me an alternative, and I will pursue it.

If you have doubts about the legality of the alternative, that's what asking me is for.

Thanks. So let's establish the groundwork and procedures before determining anything.

1) Gather but do not assess reliability of claims. If you can get in without developing reads but being nice to people do that. The idea is to get data but NOT bias.
2) Get a scum lynch without a guilty. (If we don't have that, this becomes less reliable.)
3) Establish expectations.
a) There is no clear ONE SCUM ACTION. Certain things are more indicative.
b) There are actions that are more or less town indicative. For instance, being a scum wagon suggests town.
c) Aggregate these factors. Then, make a conclusion.
d) People may disagree, but the disagreement should come from the motivation of the scumteam at that point. A wrong lynch should be able to recalibrate the theory is the hope.

I don't trust Titus' results. Here is what I've seen so far, and stop me if I'm wrong.

Titus subs in to the game. Everyone is like OMG Titus, you'll save us through VCA! Which is great if Titus is town (even though I've seen her VCA be wrong as town) but terrible if she's scum. She starts out on her VCA exercise, and everyone follows along. If she makes a misstep, never mind, she hasn't read the thread, it's OK someone will tell her and she'll adjust.

Around the time where that all started, I'd claimed a JOAT role and Lexa had revised her claim. People are thinking hang on, no way are there three JOATs in play, surely Shannon is faking it. Surely Lexa is faking her claim, why not claim properly right at the start? Then Titus claims JOAT, and suddenly ... that's plausible? It's not rendering town completely OP to have her as JOAT #3, but it is to have me? And there's totally no way there could be four of us, so I must be lying? (Look back at when I claimed my role - why would I even fake claim there, as town or scum? Why not simply say nothing and continue to play? Now ask yourself the same question about Titus).

In this light, I can see why Prana didn't want to claim. I think he's wrong in his analysis of me/Garmr vs Prana/Lexa, not least because Garmr has flipped town and I'm town too. All-town wagons do happen. They happen often enough that even newbie me has seen a few.

I accept that my stuff about Gin came out of left field. I hope we can at least see, on principle, that it's possible for scum with enough info to fake claim a plausible town role. I trusted Gin's claim until people started going after me for fake claiming, it raised my heckles and I thought hang on, someone is playing me here. And that's what I think titus has done, with greater success. She's used her information and her reputation as a VCA-solver to take a position of authority that she doesn't deserve. It's very easy for her to claim three unused JOAT shots when her predecessor lurked out all game.

For my money, the team is Titus and Lexa.

Incidentally... I've noticed people confusing MyLo and LyLo, or using them interchangeably.

MyLo or "Mislynch and Lose" is when we have an even number of players, meaning if we lynch "wrong" we lose the game as scum kill at night means we return with an even number either side and we lose that way.

LyLo or "Lynch or Lose" is when we have an odd number and we know town outnumber scum by a single person, meaning if we don't lynch at all, we are guaranteed to lose.

A tracker targeting a player who does not act, or is immune to being detected acting, will receive a result of, "[Target playername] did not visit" or similar wording thereto.
A tracker targeting a player who is immune to being targeted (e.g. Commuter when commuting, Ascetic, the target of a Rolestopper) will have their action fail and receive "No Result".

In post 2317, PranaDevil wrote:Overall, besides half the town having bloody power roles
People REALLY need to get a better sense of balance in games.
Four town roles, especially gated ones (the entirety of this game's power was designed to be used up by the end of N3!), is standard levels of town power. As in, you're basically not going to find a game with less than this in terms of town power in a mini normal. You also MASSIVELY underestimated the strength of your joat--the strongman punches through the single protection role which is already severely limited. The ninja is immune to the already severely limited tracker. If you strongman killed Gin, then the only role NOT left compromised was All Alone's JOAT--which wouldn't be able to directly catch scum aside from a lucky shot on Lexa. (Which Gin pulled anyway.) Because scum could act and kill, All Alone's fruit vend was useless filler, basically put in to have him have a third power. (It was originally a duplicate Neapolitan, but the reviewers nixed that.) All Alone's rolecop could confirm that a JOAT was what they claimed, and could catch Lexa, but was useless for vanillas. Similarly so for the Vanilla Cop: it could catch Lexa lying about being Vanilla (more on that later), but couldn't do anything otherwise. His role was basically filler, to buff the town's strength up marginally, helping to confirm town roles and in one specific instance catch the scum role but otherwise was in the game because withOUT him, your team was too strong.

In post 69, mastina wrote:So if the town mislynches Titus here, they'll have committed five of the deadly cardinal sins in a game. I'm listing them below:
Sin the first: Ignoring Lynch All Liars. "But mastina!", the town desperately cries out. "Town lie, too!" Why yes! Yes they do! Which is why you have to actually fucking EVALUATE the lie, and you've thusfar been failing to do so. In this case, run Lexa's claim through the following three-strikes rule:
STRIKE ONE: How the lie was found. Lexa told a lie with the intention of it sticking. It was only when TheRealGin-N-Tonic forcefully exposed her lie (she claimed VT, and Gin, with a Neapolitan, got a "Not a Vanilla Townie" result) that she was put in a position where she had no choice but to change her claim. Check.
STRIKE TWO: The circumstances behind the lie. Lexa claimed her motive for lying, but did it actually make sense? Why, no. No, it didn't. You let her bullshit slide without giving a thought as to whether it made sense to do her actions as town, and didn't consider if maybe her actions made more sense as scum. (They did.)
STRIKE THREE: The convenience of the claim. Lexa claimed to block known entities only. Garmr was a claimed VT. Pepchoninga was obviously flaked from the game. (More on that below.) All Alone was dead already, and unable to call her out on this (which he would have done!). There were questions as to why she didn't block other players--there weren't any in-depth inquiries as to why she DID block who she did, and while a player did bring up how "easy" the claim was...you failed to actually fucking USE that to lynch her.

Sin the second: failure to do basic setup spec. Let's look at the roles we've had claimed, and flipped. We've got a JOAT who has a rolecop and a Vanilla Cop: these powers share an obvious theme. We've got a claimed JOAT who had a doctor, jailkeep, and bodyguard: these powers share the theme of protection. We've got a claimed JOAT who had a cop, gunsmith, and neapolitan: these powers share the theme of being hard investigatives. We've got a claimed JOAT who has a track, follow, and motion detector: these powers share the theme of being tracker-variant powers. We've got a claimed full-Roleblocker.
...
...
...One of these things is not like the others. Lynch the odd woman out.

Sin the third: failure to do basic interactions. Who could Titus actually be scum with? Realistically. Her reads are scattered all over the place, lacking strong cohesion. The little she's pushed suggests strongly she's not scum with PranaDevil. The fact that PranaDevil and shannon both heavily suspect her indicates she's less likely to be their scumbuddies, too. The only possibilities are TheRealGin-N-Tonic and Lexa, but more on the Lexa scenario below. She's a universal scumread. That means, every player--literally every player in the game--is calling her scum. Which means one of two things: either her scumbuddy is bussing her...or FAR more likely (and this is the reason a failure to do basic interactions is a cardinal sin!), she's the town mislynch in lylo: scum want her dead and so do town.

Sin the fourth: failure to consider the circumstances of the game in relationship to the slot. Pepchoninga was in the process of siteflaking at the end of D1. D2 and D3 were quicklynches, so I was unable to replace the slot. It wasn't until I was presented with evidence of the siteflake that I could replace the slot on D4. This told the town that Pepchoninga was unable to do anything. In other words, Titus as town would have all of her powers, or be scum with a scumbuddy who was playing solo for two if not THREE of the game's nights--figure out who said scumbuddy would be before so much as considering a lynch on Titus, because Titus would not be the one driving the nightkills.

Sin the fifth: failure to apply occam's razor. Which makes more sense? Titus claimed a role which perfectly fit into the game as scum, when she hadn't even read the game and was in a slot which hadn't played since D1...OR, that Titus had a role which was actually fucking in the game?
Furthermore, which of the below scenarios makes the most sense?
Titus is scum, and Lexa is also scum. Titus claims a result indicating she is blocked, and Lexa is a claimed roleblocker. They did this to establish distance. (If you somehow believe this, then the correct move is...fucking lynching Lexa.)
Titus is scum with shannon, Lexa is a town roleblocker. Titus, knowing Lexa is a roleblocker, claims a result indicating she is blocked, knowing Lexa is going to have a claim which contradicts her.
Titus is scum with someone else, Lexa is town. Titus, knowing Lexa is a roleblocker AND that shannon had a jailkeeper, claims a result indicating she is blocked, in spite of knowing Lexa is going to claim a result which will contradict her.
Titus is town, Lexa is a town roleblocker. Titus got blocked, yet Lexa truthfully blocked PranaDevil, meaning that Titus was blocked by either shannon or TheRealGin-N-Tonic.
OR.
How about, without speculating about any other things.
Titus is town. Lexa, the claimed roleblocker, roleblocked Titus, and lied about who she blocked.

That is the simplest scenario. No twists. No assumptions. No crazy wacky shenanigans. One simple theory, using known facts.

This is why the town should be lynching Lexa.
And this is why a failure to do so would be a perfect instance of why those fatal five flaws are cardinal sins of townplay.
There was a failure to evaluate Lexa's lie (strike against mindset, motive, and intention, three of my FOUNDING PRINCIPLES OF THEORY WORK), failure to pay attention to circumstances (strike against circumstances, ANOTHER of my founding principles of theory work), failure to apply occam's razord (strike against KISS, ANOTHER of my founding principles of theory work), AND failure to do basic interactions (strike against interactions, one of THE first principles of theory work I did!). The only sin listed here which isn't a part of my theory work so much as it is basic common sense is the setup spec point.

Overall a really fun game, and an enjoyable return to the site for me.

A few things i wasn't a fan of, which i mentioned for discussion purposes, and also possible future changes.

Too many power roles, waaaay too many power roles for town. 3 already seemed OP, 4 was crazy. I'm not sure where that was deemed normal, but it definitely didn't feel "normal" with how it went. I'm all for crazy stuff going on, (hence my /in for oddrole), but my aim was to be in a nice, relatively basic game for my first one back, and this was anything but. Definitely feel like it shouldn't have been in the normal queue.

And to respond to mastina's post above, the reason it was OP is that, yes, while Lexa's JOAT could hit some of them, we basically were three goons, because Lexa's JOAT shots rely on us knowing who the other roles are, where they are firing, and with what. Having a ninja kill is fine, but a one shot where we have no clue if it's essentially being wasted means it's actually rather a weak shot, ditto with the strongman. Yes if we know there's a doc and it's protecting a specific slot we can override, but there was only a tiny chance that was ever going to happen, thus in reality it was two goons, and a one shot roleblocker, against 4 town PRs, three of which had investigative powers and could potentially confirm each other.

Too much mod chatter as well. There were times I felt like perhaps mastina was giving too much info about things, and the pissing about from everyone to get page tops... that did legitimately annoy me somewhat as it stops being part of the game at that point. (Ditto for what I called Alisae's "shit posting", regardless of alignment, I stand by the fact that we don't need that stuff outside of RVS).

Good stuff was regular vote counts (if need be, edit a players post, or just stick them in anywhere, we're all big enough to ISO the mod if we need to), and barring the known issue of being away at weekends (which is fair enough) mastina was usually on the ball quite often to sort stuff. (Game end not permitting... )

Player base was fun, barring the one obvious issue with Garmr, who, if he ever plays the game again, needs to understand that nobody is required to take his word for anything, and the entire game is based around working out who is most probable scum in any situation.

karnos needs to not hoist his own lynch quite so quick when he's scum in future too, I mean, my god man, day 1?!

I'm sure other stuff will come up when I think of it, or when people read the scum thread, but regardless of anything I said in here, I mean no ill will to anyone, play to the role and all that jazz after all.

Like I said.
This game is an example of standard site balance.
This is what most games on the site SHOULD have. (Or close thereto.)

It has been shown, time and time again, the town needs power roles in order to win the game--absolutely NEED them. It has been shown through many threads across time, countless reviewers having gathered the data to show, optimum town power is 3-4 town roles. (Incidentally, me including All Alone's JOAT was not a guarantee--when the review thread is released, you'll note that I basically said: "I will have three JOATs if you think that is closer to balanced, or four JOATs if you think THAT is closer to balanced, because it'd be really really close either way". Unanimously, the reviewers voted for four rather than three.) Not 1. Not 2. Those are the numbers you need in a MICRO. For a mini, you absolutely REQUIRE 3-4 essentially. That's the site standard, because that's what towns require. Less than 3 is universally scumsided, even if your two roles happen to be cop-doc. More than 4, sure, swings towards townsided. But 3-4 is the butter zone of balance.

Furthermore, I actually violated one of my own guidelines as a reviewer this game, albeit accidentally. You had a ninja shot which basically negated the power of a tracker. I've gone on record to say that ninjas to counter trackers are just plain unfair. (This was because in an iteration of the setup prior to me entering review, it was a Watcher/Voyeur/Motion Detector Joat + the Cop-Joat + the Doc-Joat, and when I realized how much of a hilariously bad idea that combo was even with a scum strongman-ninja JOAT I altered the setup to almost its current form, so you having a ninja shot was a relic I accidentally forgot about.)

This basically made your role tailored to all the town's roles: you had the perfect counter to them, something I am usually adamantly against as a reviewer. (Also, as I noted: you KNEW there was a tracker JOAT in the game, via having a ninja shot. You KNEW there was a protection-JOAT in the game, via having a strongman shot. You might not have known they were JOATs, but when All Alone flipped JOAT, and Gin claimed JOAT, it wasn't too hard for you to figure out that with your OWN JOAT, the game's roles all had a theme to them. This gave you insider knowledge as to the setup composition WELL before the town had a clue.) This game would have been RIDICULOUSLY scumsided if it had been only three JOATs against your JOAT. As-is, if this game was imbalanced in any direction it would be towards scum, not towards the town.

As for confirming information: I did nothing of the sort. I answered questions about my process which were public information, readily available to any who would ask. All the information I divulged is readily available. I am obliged to answer about how my modding process works. (For instance, prod rules.) I am obliged to answer about how roles interact. I am obligated to answer about how a role which could be in the game would work--these are no guarantees those roles are actually in the game, because I make it my policy to hold answer for EVERY possible role in the game I can think of. (And as a Normal reviewer, I tend to have fairly good knowledge of the roles we have which're Normal, and aside from one or two disagreements with how the Normal role works, I have their mechanics in Normal games basically memorized.)

If a player assumes I confirm knowledge that I am not in fact confirming, that is their prerogative. They do so mistakenly. If their assumption is correct, then it is right-for-the-wrong-reasons. It just as easily could be an assumption which is incorrect, in which it is wrong because it is wrong reasoning. I gave information as it was pertinent. Any information given was given at prompting. It did nothing but clarify stances on what was already public information.

So when the town quicklynched TWICE in a ROW, delaying the replacement through normal legal means, I was rather frustrated: an essential core aspect of the town's power, one of their central roles, was out of the game for the entire duration the rest of the town's powers were expected to be in play. And I as the moderator was powerless to replace the slot because if I had suddenly replaced Pepchoninga going into, say, N2, it would be a big gigantic neon sign of, "THIS SLOT HAS A POWER ROLE AND THAT IS WHY I NEED IT IN THE GAME", so I couldn't replace it then.

I also couldn't replace the slot off of just players saying "I think that he siteflaked" (even though I knew that was true), because "I think" can, and was, proven wrong, such as when Garmr was thought to leave but then came back. (I mean, in hindsight given his actions it would have been better for the game's health if he WAS replaced, but the simple fact is, he did in fact come back so the only grounds I would have had to replace him is on policy via a force-replace, and at that time, he hadn't crossed a line that would justify doing so.)

So while I couldn't exactly say, "THANK YOU FOR FINALLY GIVING ME THE LEGAL GROUNDS TO DO THIS!" to Gin when Gin gave me evidence of the siteflake, I was very much happy that I could finally actually replace the slot. (Granted, this was a damned-if-I did, damned-if-I-didn't scenario: Pepchoninga having siteflaked meant that Pepchoninga could not have contributed anything during the night, but given that Titus was the lylo mislynch, I think I ultimately made the right call in this being the least-damaging of the options available.)

In future games, when a quicklynch happens (rare as those are), I'm thinking of instilling a rule: Sending a form of mass-prod to confirm all players are actually playing. "I must hear from EVERY player during the night. If a player fails to respond, deadline for night will be suspended and the slot will be replaced".

The other frustration was, obviously, Garmr. That was not something I wanted to deal with in my games, ever. Generally if a player is showing signs of toxicity, I will force-replace them. But prior to the day Garmr exploded, he was within normal boundaries. Players weren't being upset by him, and his language--while a bit on the harsher side--wasn't crossing any lines. I didn't even recall seeing any instance of him using language warranting a warning, though if I missed any (which is possible, because as a mod I tend to skim somewhat), my apologies.

Yet, even though the sample VT PM is public...Garmr quoted his role PM all the same--and even IF that weren't itself enough, he had it with TIMESTAMPS. As a mod, you really don't have any other choice at that point because that's just about as unambiguous as unambiguous can get, of being a quote of a role PM. Awkwardly enough, the thought of a modkill never really crossed my mind in my ruleset. It's something that moderators only do as an absolute last resort. (Or, well, SHOULD do only as an absolute last resort.) After doing thorough research and confirming the slot itself is in fact compromised. (A slot can still be saved often via a force-replace.)

I mean. I have a rule covering modkills: site rules as a rule in a game, because site rules have as a rule not to quote role PMs. But said site rule doesn't cover what to actually do when a modkill IS necessary. And while I did at one time have a rule on how to handle a modkill, it has not been in my rules for games upon games, years upon years, so I was left in the rather frustrating position of not knowing how to actually handle it. Obviously, the slot would be modkilled, and turned neutral survivor. But what would happen after the modkill? I didn't know.

Nexus personally told me how he resets votecounts and continues the phase, so ultimately, that is what I elected to do--I also figured that if the town WANTED the day to end without a lynch after the modkill, they could simply elect to vote for a no-lynch, which ended up being exactly what they did. Butstill, the game was irreparably damanged by the modkill, because modkills are always something which cause a game to be irreparable, and it was...unpleasant.

Incidentally, while I wanted to run a series of Majesty Mafia games next, I don't yet have them close enough to ready to run them.
What I DO have ready are a couple of micros.
One, "The Joke's On You", would be an openly 6:2:1 town:mafia:jester, where if the jester is lynched, both the town and the mafia lose.
Two, "The Murderer", would be a heavily-flavored open 8:1 vanilla town:serial killer mountainous game with a safeguard against the game ending D1.
Three, "Movie Mafia", not quite ready to be released yet (format's not final), would be a game where players are supposed to follow a "script". This script would be public: players know who gets lynched on what days, and who dies during what nights. What WOULDN'T be public would be the flips of said players. Scum would have a "flip the script" power and be able to, on certain occasions, alter the script as they will it.

I also want to eventually make a Kongregate Games mafia (a small large theme, like, 15 players or so), but that's nowhere near close to ready.
Then there's also Agnigi, the sequel game to Gistou. (Mini theme.)
Not to mention, Hilariously Unbalanced 3, a large theme I've needed to work on for ages.

However, in spite of all of the above, what I really want to run, above all other games, is a game called Aurum.
It's not quite ready yet (I need to write the role PMs, get some coherence from game reviewers and final checks and whatnot), but the basic pitch behind the game:

The game will be an openly 7:2:2:2 mini theme multiball with a ridiculously large amount of flavor.
Spoiler: Flavor Text (may get changed some later)
History of Aurum
As written by the greatest sage gaya will ever know.

Aurum.
The promised land.

The trouble with any "promised land" is that everyone has a different idea of what, exactly, it is which was 'promised'. Or even if they happen to agree on the nature of the promise, they tend to have a disagreement on to whom it is promised to. However, aside from the inherent nature of humanity, one thing is universally clear: it was agreed upon (with only minimal argument) this land represented a paradise on gaya, one oasis of mystical miracles of magic in a land otherwise fraught with fragility and futility.

A sacred land, largely it had been unknown to the barbaric world outside. For inside, this golden haven held such lucrative riches that those who had previously chosen to settle within had long-since learned to never venture back. Still, with the progress of time, the inevitable would occur, and eventually, word of this place once thought to be nothing but mere legend and myth rose forth.

Adventurers and explorers from across gaya entered the land, documenting their findings and sending back gifts to the foreign powers they were sent to represent. Soon, news spread, and what had once been a land of only a few natives saw the frontiersmen founding some initial settlements, free from the oppression of the outside world.

Unfortunately, as humans are humans, conflict would soon arise. Within this neutral territory, no rules had been established. Soon the inhabitants had some mutual understandings. (Surprisingly, these actually were, in fact, immune to blunder and rather unambiguous.) Though not written into laws, a universal truth was presented: This land was meant to be shared with all within, and those that wished to live their lives fully and happily within would be welcome. Boundaries broke down between cultures and people, as they began to find common ground in their freedom from fighting.

They even established a home, where trading posts, local tribes, and outposts blended together to form the city ofAltaria, the city of the lake, the greatest gathering of people in the region and central hub of activity, to the point where many even began to call it the capital city of all Aurum, with the implication of a strong sense of independence, and yet, community.

This, itself, would be no problem. However, understandably, those powers that these immigrants had once been a part of did not exactly approve of what they saw as treason. Their subjects were effectively deserting them, and instead of harvesting the wealth and bounty of the supernatural sacred land, they were instead keeping it all to themselves. This was, to them, unacceptable, especially as doubt, paranoia, and fear of the other nations exploiting these tools came forward.

To best understand this situation, it would perhaps be best to rewind time, and to talk about what shaped gaya to be as it was when Aurum was first found. Any child who has received so much as basic tutoring would know about the nature of gaya, as humanity studies the thirteen moon cycles and their corresponding star cycles from birth, assuming of course an individual holds any wish to have so much as a chance of harvesting magic.

It should then need not be said how magic has so shaped the path of history, and how the shifting zodiacs from moonth to moonth over the given year affect the outcome of mortal affairs. In case someone has somehow managed to obtain the skill of literacy while being utterly ignorant to such workings, they need only pay attention to the world around them, feeling their inner strength on their birth date as their zodiac shines brightly in the sky, especially on the new moon for which their zodiac reigns over at the beginning of a moonth.

Gaya, the home of known humanity, is an isolated land itself. It has long-since been calculated that gaya represents a mere fraction of the total circumference of the total world, and speculated that much land mass must exist beyond the borders of gaya itself. However, due to the nature of the land, humanity had always been cut off on all sides, having a mere two continents in close proximity.

To the east lies a seemingly endless desert, where the sun saps all magic dry and the moon fails to supply. This desolate landscape spans miles of terrain, all appearing identical to the naked eye. With the stars themselves granting no strength, all attempts to map the terrain have failed, and traditional methods prove too much of a logistical impossibility to know for sure what lies on the other end. The shifting sands, as they are colloquially called, offer no signs of life and no protection from the fatigue of traveling within.

To the north lies the frozen northern mountains, where the constant cloud covering renders magic inert. Attempts to find a passageway through them have been made, all ending in failure as expeditions either perished without a trace or turned back when the air proved too thin to breathe. The constant rumbling of the mountains prove why tunneling efforts have always been foiled, as the passageways soon collapse not long after they are made.

The greatest hope of escape most humanity holds on gaya is that to the west, where the salty water resides. However, even there, turmoil is a constant. To the northwest, there is documented evidence of a theoretical passage, yet treacherous typhoons consistently keep wrecking any ship who has the courage (rather, the stupidity) to try. The journey to the southwest shows only an endless ocean of water, one where the zodiacs intermingle, become blurred, and interfere with clear magic usage. Given the limited supplies a ship can carry and the lack of material to provide a restock, humanity had gone as far as possible with their current means as of Aurum's discovery.

With this limited set of resources and land, gaya has, naturally, had a fair share of fighting. TheVatnaq, a seafaring group of tribes reformed under the tyrant king Albert the Great, had long-since conquered the island-continent ofHeimcasand moved inland to the main gaya continent. Their sturdy ships were versatile to traverse both ocean and river, even able to survive crossings over land. This dominant navy allowed them to claim dominion over much of gaya's main water routes, establishing an empire of colonies and trade, paying tribute toAlberta, their capital.

The expansion of the Vatnaq was halted by theRoyal Bareed Empire, their rivals to the north. A hardy, sturdy people, the Baridians were the conquerors of theOken region, spanning across the entirety of the north, into the fertile plains in the middle of gaya, and stretching all the way to the deserts where they found their natural limit. Originally a small tribe of one great city,Krasivya, they were a militant people led by generals who were actually competent at their job, slowly expanding from their humble beginnings until the king of kings Alexander cemented his rule, as all his heirs would succeed him as The Great King.

However, while his descendants continued in his name, King of Kings Alexander was himself slain in battle by the prophet of the desert empire ofHaraphet. A culture of tribal philosophers, they are credited as the first to have studied the magical connection between humanity and theZodiacs, though it should be noted the Vatnaq were the first to actually make use of this knowledge, and the Haraphin did not themselves map out the system of zodiacs.

Prior ancient civilizations, long-since assimilated into the empires, had in distant times done this work already. Though these older civilizations still, as vassals, existed at the time of Arum's discovery, they had lost their relevancy to the history books, being subservient to one of the three great powers. The Vatnaq honor their fallen rivals and the Haraphin attribute their success to their fore-bearers, with only the Baridians seeking total cultural assimilation. Thanks to this dynamic, the exact trigger which caused the rise of the Haraphin is unknown, but it is generally thought they rose to power over theKizmathanks to the prophetBaskiis named after, Bask the diviner. She saved her people from disaster and warned them of incoming invasion, and it is thought that once they were given the motivation to fight, they expanded their borders as far as they would reach.

Some areas outside of Aurum remain unaligned to a great nation, yet have proven to be neverending warzones, trapped forever in a cycle of pointless violence. These historical footnotes are of little relevance, and the nations are the ones known to have influenced the history of Aurum. The last great war was an impressively long 58 years prior to the discovery of Aurum, yet tensions were naturally high. With Aurum entering the equation, there was a risk in the equilibrium being disrupted, and those in power would not take kindly to losing it.

The problem for Aurum is that no one nation could claim sole dominion over it. Aside from it being undiscovered, neutral territory, its location is within the natural borders on the edge of the Haraphin Caliphate and the Royal Bareed Empire. The mountains are magically enchanted to repel any effort of entering, except through the underground passageways...all of which were known to be within the territory of the Vatnaq.

It should be noted on the historical record that the legend of Aurum, prior to its discovery, contained plenty of rumors about being able to grant immortality. Though the land certainly was healthy, Aruniansassumed this was a mere exaggeration of the natural healing waters and magical enhancements within the golden land.

All the same, it is of course obvious that many would be allured by the promise of something they would never receive, as all too many initial pilgrims were so disappointed to learn. However, while the long-term residents could of course tell the three empires that this alleged immortality was nothing more than mere myth, this is of course something which would only cause their leaders' paranoia to increase further that it did, and was being kept from them.

Naturally, these leaders thought they would be fit to rule forever, and thus, would deserve the immortality of the land, and so, fighting was inevitable. Aurum, for all its myriad of blessings, could not offer all it was promised to give. No nation wanted to accept that. Nor would any power willingly let another take an edge away from them. Thus, the first conflict of Aurum was born.

To settle this before it would begin, it was unilaterally decided by some genius that 13 delegates--one for each moon cycle to represent every zodiac--would somehow be anonymously nominated, elected, then selected, and to traverse to a secret meeting site where surely nothing could go wrong. Somehow, it was thought these individuals would carry the weight where they would agree once and for all on how to handle Aurum.

To their credit, this peaceful gathering would forbid any and all weapons--even any equipment made from the nipe tree (especially staves and wands) would be forbidden from entry, as to prevent any possible magical interference or subterfuge. On good faith if nothing less, this would ensure that events would miraculously go smoothly.

And in their hopeless idealism, the Arunians actually honored this agreement: their representatives would have no knowledge of each other or of the motives of their fellow delegates. They truly believed, as per typical Arunian naivety, that their natural strength would triumph and good nature would win.

Unsurprisingly, the three nations did not share this belief: they cheated, each suspecting the others would anyway, so they might as well act in kind, stacking the deck in their favor as much as they could. Not only were their representatives given foreknowledge of their ally, but also provided with unique magical buffs that would render them able to remotely remove a representative's life force from them in unique ways.

How did the Arunian's discover this? For all the shortcomings of their stunning plan, the ones responsible for putting this together were not entirely moronic. The potential for malice was anticipated in advance, and accounted for: when all delegates had arrived, an automatic spell was triggered to sense deceit. This may have actually worked, if not for having nearly half the delegates holding ulterior motives. While certainly a smart idea in theory, in practice with so many in the room acting in ill will, it was impossible to pinpoint so much as a single source, and thus, the representatives would have to deal with the problem manually.

Though the treachery proved to be only slightly surprising (and was naturally none to those owing allegiance to the nations, albeit they were inconvenienced by being so exposed), it would, if not dealt with, prove to be quite the inconvenience for the summit, who would now need to act fast in order to remove opposition, or risk their agenda being lost.

To deal with this, someone--history records not whom--came up with the brilliant solution to, as a council, one by one elect to isolate members and cast them out, even if doing so would prove fatal. This ostracization would be accomplished by a simple majority vote on whom to cast out.

And thus what would be known as The Zodiac Debate thereafter would soon begin...

Spoiler: Game Mechanics (may be revised slightly)
Game Mechanics:

Gamerules of Gaya
  • Though this game is HEAVILY flavored, there is no obvious town or obvious scum flavor. Every player's flavor will give the background of their character, but said background will NOT include any information about their given allegiance. As a result, no fakeclaims will be necessary. (However, if a scum player should so request altered flavor for an ability they wish to fakeclaim, I shall provide it.)
  • This game is openly 7:2:2:2 multiball. It is not bastard. (Just insane.)
    • The town faction of this game are the residents of Aurum, the Arunians.
    • There are three scum factions: the Vatnaq, Baridians, and Haraphin.
  • The Arunian (town) wincon is as follows: "You win when all threats to Aurum are eliminated, and at least one member of the Arunian faction is alive."
  • The scum wincon is as follows: "You win when the (scum faction) faction controls 50% of the council, and nothing can prevent this."
  • Mind Link: (Telepathy.) Any and all topics this game will be open the entire duration of the game. In other words, scum have daychat.
  • Black Magic: Unless specifically noted otherwise in their role PM, mafia may use their factional abilities at the same time they use any other abilities they possess. In other words, they can both kill and action.
    • Every player will have a kill source unique to them.
  • In this game, every player has three unique attributes separate from wincon:
    1. Region of Origin, of which there are five possibilities:
      1. Aurum
      2. Heimcas
      3. Oken
      4. Kizma
      5. None established
    2. Capital City of Highest Affiliation, of which there are five possibilities:
      1. Altaria
      2. Alberta
      3. Krasivya
      4. Baski
      5. No city affiliation
    3. Zodiac Sign, of which there are thirteen:
      1. Phoenix
      2. Hen
      3. Ox
      4. Chimera
      5. Bear
      6. Wolf
      7. Lion
      8. Tiger
      9. Dragon
      10. Scorpion
      11. Serpent
      12. Owl
      13. Raven
  • Upon the death of a player, I will provide the full details of their role PM except faction-specific sections.
  • No player is entirely vanilla! This is because every player, unless otherwise specified, has a free action they may perform in addition to any other action they may possess. This action cannot be prevented from happening (i.e. is immune to roleblock-type actions), though success is not guaranteed (e.g. redirection, target immunity). This check action allows for a player to learn the region, city, and zodiac of a target player.
  • This game will use my best understanding of Natural Action Resolution. If you have a question about an interaction, ask; I shall do my best to answer.
  • While there are seven or more players alive, I will not answer questions about endgame scenarios, aside from some obvious ones.
  • I realize this is a crazy game in which most people are here to have fun, but until such a time where it is literally impossible to do so, you are expected to play towards a WIN. As in, your faction victorious and all other factions losing. If you're the last townie in a 1:2:2:2 game, too bad, you're still expected to try and win (as with the right crosskills, it is in fact possible for a lone townie to win!). You knew the game type when you signed up.
I really really really really want to run this game even though it's not quite ready yet to be run, so that's probably what I'm going to be doing next if you're interested in playing a mastina-modded game again. <3
